title.narrative: Health Fruit and Vegetables for South Africa

description.narrative: In Southern and Eastern Africa, we facilitated country-specific multi-stakeholder platforms in South Africa, Zambia, Tanzania and Uganda, bringing together private sector i.e. buyers, retail and traders, producers, and regulating and government bodies, and co designing and aligning food safety and sustainability policies for the fruits and vegetables value chain. Ultimately, we aim for a continental benchmarking system. A major success was achieved in South Africa, with making GLOBALGAP more smallholder inclusive by adopting the Primary Farm Assurance (PFA) Standard, a lower entry level standard for small scale fruit and vegetable farmers.

2017 has highlighted that while there was overall agreement on the need for a SHF inclusion in F&V supply chains in SA, the specific interests, politics and dynamics of sector stakeholder have proven to make it difficult to have this agenda lead to concrete joint actions.

title.narrative: # of brands and companies (private partners) supported to implement national, re

comment.narrative: MSP unravelled in 2018. Companies are hesitant to adopt, let alone commit to developing an integrated standard. as each company has their own standard they use. Our approach will therefore change - please see reprot for more details.

title.narrative: RTs & VSS generate normative frameworks and funding mechanisms
Description of the sustainability issues and/or land issues on the agenda

description.narrative: 1 Multi-stakeholder agreed agenda for improvement of issues within SHP market access

comment.narrative: 1 Multi-stakeholder agreed agenda for improvement of issues within SHP market access

There was an overall agreement between various stakeholder (including CSOs) about developing a shared agenda towards an integrated standard, resource sharing and information sharing to find ways to proactively and effectively manage food safety, environmental and social compliance in South Africa. Despite this, there remains a barrier in terms of securing buy-in from retailers who seemingly anticipate a risk to competitive advantage should they collaborate with other retailers on a tool/standard to bridge SHF with localGAP. Collaborative efforts continued in 2017. One of the goals for 2017 was also to develop funded partnerships and/or match funding to ensure the sustainability of the multi-stakeholder platform, however, this has not been achieved at the pace anticipated, given that fundraising is a slow paced process. Funding has been secured from Switch Africa Green fund for work in 2018, and we anticipate building on this momentum in 2018.

comment.narrative: 13 stakeholders engaged about formation and organisation of a MSP for the sector and development of health and safety F&V standard for Zambia.

title.narrative: # + kind of stakeholders that convened or participating in MSPs, networks or di

comment.narrative: For sustainability purposes, the project introduced a self-cover of costs for project activities e.g. no allowances to attend MSPs in 2018. Therefore, the number of stakeholders who participated in MSPs in 2018 reduced because of lack of funds to cover for their respective costs

comment.narrative: In terms of targeted support, we support Kasisi who represents a range of smallholder farmers, participate in the dialogues in 2018 around the need for a Standard

title.narrative: # CSOs that are being trained or supported in decision making and dialogue

comment.narrative: While no formal MSP took place in 2018, three CSOs and one PO (AFASA, WWF, ICCO and Lima Development Foundation) participated in decision making around the development of the Farming Solution sustainability toolkit and are participating in the piloting of the toolkit.
